11:11 am
BE11:12am

Complicating interpretation of the reports emerging from the pre-meeting is discussion around nominal barrels - gross quota changes - and the effective barrels i.e. the barrels that will emerge in 2H which will be determined by the gross and the available capacity to raise production, which in many cases is lower. Our base case is that a figure that nets out at 500-600kbd in 2H over 2Q would balance the market.

BE11:13am

And Panmure ....

BE11:13am

OPEC has reportedly reached a preliminary agreement to boost production by a nominal 1mmbd. However, the Iranian delegation walked out of the Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee with Iran’s oil minister, Bijan Zanganeh, again saying OPEC was unlikely to reach an agreement.
It is unclear whether the 1mmbd figure refers just to OPEC itself or to OPEC+. In our view the latter is more likely and would represent an
increase of ~2% in current targets. Assuming that is spread equally across the group we estimate that it would result in an actual increase in
production of around 600kbd which should leave the market reasonably comfortably balanced. We suspect it is more likely than not that an
agreement will be reached since no agreement is likely to result in unilateral action from Saudi Arabia and its allies together with Russia and
in the end we expect Iran would prefer such an outcome to occur within the context of a formal agreement. We also look for a potential
Autumn meeting to be scheduled since issues such as a continuing collapse in Venezuelan production do not look like they will be formally
accommodated in a structure with continues to pretend that all countries are able to make their production targets. We would not be
surprised if OPEC did not publish targets by country. It will also be interesting to see what justification is cited for the decision, now that the
previous focus on returning OECD inventory to the five-year average looks redundant. We would expect such an outcome to put some further
pressure on prices but probably leave them trading around the US$70/bbl mark until the actual direction of global inventories becomes more
apparent, which is likely to take several months.

BE11:19am

All parties agree to expand Shaikan production to 55 kbopd first stage. Gulf Keystone, the KRG MNR, and Shaikan field partner MOL have reached agreement on investment plans to increase the field's production to 55 kbopd over the next 12-18 months. This is a key step for GKP and its partners as it allows the companies to start the process of unlocking the full potential of the Shaikan field (gross 2P reserves 600 mmbbls) and it establishes a close relationship between the partners to realise production growth for mutual benefit.

BE11:20am

Shaikan is performing very well with plant uptime of 99% so far this year, and average production to end May of 32.1kbopd, above the upper end of 27-32 kbopd guidance for FY18. Although guidance is unchanged the continuing strong field delivery is very encouraging for the expanded development of Shaikan. The field has now produced 50 mmbbls from only nine wells, further demonstrating its quality and scope for increased production. With that cumulative production milestone a production bonus of $20m gross is payable to the KRG.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

We derisk the commercial/investment part of our overall Shaikan risking to 100% CoS from 90%. As a result, our Shaikan risking now stands at 95% - simply to reflect some residual field development execution risk. This increases our NPV15 central valuation to 273p/sh from 249p/sh.

We raise our TP to 275p/sh from 250p/sh.

Oh, and Genel!

11:21 am
Genel Energy PLC (GENL:LSE): Last: 261.00, up 6.5 (+2.55%), High: 263.50, Low: 250.50, Volume: 414.40k
BE11:22am

Numis this time.

BE11:23am

Whilst the shares have performed strongly year-to-date [+155%], leaving more modest upside based upon our current risk assessment, we see substantial potential to de-risk our estimates if projects proceed to development. For example a standalone development of Bina Bawi oil could, on an un-risked basis, see our NAV rise to 370p/sh, offering ~40% upside.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Importantly, we believe Genel could fund an oil development at Bina Bawi at its current 100% interest; unlike the gas project, execution for the oil is not reliant upon farm-outs. This makes a Bina Bawi oil development a potentially valuable catalyst over the next 12-18 months. Bina Bawi gas could further increase this to 424p/sh, offering ~60% upside, and Miran gas could increase this to 484p/sh, offering ~80% upside. The 30% chance of success we currently attribute for these projects reflects both the technical and commercial uncertainties of development, which Genel aims to tackle. Genel's portfolio has potential to deliver up to 4x production growth by 2025 on our un-risked estimates, and the balance sheet outlook is much improved. We forecast continued FCF generation whilst delivering production growth, a debt neutral position by year-end 2018, and our forecast for 2025 cash has improved by US$0.9bn over the last 16 months. We upgrade our target price to 290p/sh from 185p/sh and move our rating to Add from Buy, reflecting lower upside following strong share price performance, whilst we await further visibility around de-risking of the projects. Genel trades at 0.91x our discovered resource NAV, a premium to the large cap E&P average of 0.79x.

Excel Developer Klaus ReglingManaging Director of the European Stability Mechanism
BE11:29am

The debt relief agreed is bigger than we had expected. In particular,
the 10-year extension of the EFSF loans’ maturity and most importantly the grace period on interest payments is a significant development. Eurozone governments had agreed last year that any extension would be between 0-15 years. The extension is especially notable given that it is not subject to certain criteria. The cash buffer is also important to ease the transition period after the bailout ends. It is, of course, good news that the IMF gave the debt agreement its blessing although it will not activate its planned lifeline for Greece – something that the Fund had previously said that it would do once the country’s Eurozone creditors took sufficient steps to ensure its debt remained sustainable in the long term. As the IMF will not actively participate in the programmes, its influence is limited. Overall, this was a positive outcome for Greece, in our view.

RobinHood Anything on impact of CO2 shortage?
BE11:29am

And Deutsche.

bones30 I see that would have been the 30,000s now.
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Many structural challenges remain but both sides wished to achieve a positive outcome and move away from the era of official assistance programmes in the euro-area’s periphery.

BE11:30am

The agreement entails stronger monitoring - by EU authorities and IMF - and conditionality than in previous programme exits. In addition to quarterly “enhanced surveillance” reviews, promises of debt-relief and less fiscal pressure will be staggered over time and not granted
immediately. The European authorities hope that this will provide the right incentives for Greece to comply with its engagements.

BE11:30am

As expected, the focus of the latest debt-relief measures was on the
medium-term (5 years) to ensure Greece slowly regains market access
over the next decade. Extensions of 10 years to ~€100bn of EFSF loans
instead of the maximum 15 years were a concession to the German side.
Eurosystem profits of~€5bn should be returned to Greece over the next
five years. Also, €15bn out of the €40bn remaining in the third programme
envelope will be used to build up the current cash buffer to €24bn,
sufficient to cover the financing needs until Summer 2020.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

In the very long-term (beyond the next decade), as long as Greece shows
the political commitment to remain aligned with Europe, the political
economy of the situation - Greek commitment and EU pragmatism/
flexibility - should shroud the exact financial arithmetic of traditional debtsustainability
exercises. Greece will have to maintain a relatively healthy
fiscal performance, growth rates aligned with the euro-area average and
stable politics. Brussels tends to perceive Portugal, Ireland and Spain as
success stories post-crisis providing a tangible roadmap to follow.

willosaurus Anecdote: Mother in law tried to buy some Meindl boots recently - told none available in foreseeable future as German army has bought up the entire output. Hopefully an effort to meet NATO spending commitments rather than preparations for some serious marching!

BE11:32am

In the short term, due to the establishment of a cash buffer of roughly EUR24bn, the positive growth outlook in Greece and in the Euro area, and the very accommodative monetary policy stance of the ECB, Greece should be able to make a successful comeback to market, even though Greek bonds will be affected by developments in Italy. Eurogroup officials stated that the cash buffer would cover 22 months of Greek liabilities.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

On a medium-term basis, our own debt sustainability analysis shows that the fiscal targets set for Greece are demanding (3.5% primary surplus until 2022, and an average primary surplus of 2.2% thereafter), and that under more realistic assumptions on the primary surplus and nominal growth gross funding needs would rise more rapidly than anticipated by the European Commission. That said, the Eurogroup’s commitment to reconsider a further reprofiling of the EFSF loan at the end of the grace period in 2032 highlights that de facto the official sector loan is considered junior to the private sector loan. A further extension to the maturity of this loan is the base case in our view, provided Greece maintains fiscally responsible economic policies, though at this timeframe there is a high degree of uncertainty.

Excel Developer @Bryce: 3 separate analysts, you are really spoiling me, Monsieur!
BE11:32am

At this juncture, the potential risks we could foresee are political risks related to the electoral cycle. Any future government that does not maintain the implemented reforms and decides to pursue expansionary fiscal policies could put this framework at risk. That said, at least for now, it seems unlikely that now that the economy is recovering and full market access is in sight, political parties would put this in jeopardy. At this stage, there may be external risks to the programme too from political developments in Germany and more so in Italy.

Over the last three months, 9 of the top 14 performing stocks in our European Capital Goods coverage are from the UK [despite being less than one-third of our team coverage]. Short-cycle data has been exceptionally strong over the last six months, with the US, German, UK and many other PMIs hitting or passing pre-crisis peaks.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

While the longevity of growth is still an open debate, we see limited scope for further outperformance and downgrade three short-cycle exposed names: Bodycote [to Sell from Neutral], and Spectris and Renishaw [to Neutral from Buy]. We are 11% below 2020E Bloomberg consensus EBIT for Bodycote and, while short-cycle names such as SKF/Fastenal de-rate, Bodycote’s valuation remains close to relative multi-year highs. Meanwhile, for Spectris and Renishaw, since adding them to the Buy List on December 12, 2017 and April 3, 2018, respectively, the shares are up 14%/25% vs. -2%/4% for the FTSE World Europe index. Our favoured UK Buy remains Melrose [on CL] where we see scope for 20p of EPS by 2020 [c.15% ahead of updated company-compiled consensus] and significant shareholder returns as disposals materialise.

ASOS PLC (ASC:LSE): Last: 6,316, down 290 (-4.39%), High: 6,502, Low: 6,232, Volume: 314.07k
Boohoo.Com PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 200.00, down 5.8 (-2.82%), High: 206.40, Low: 195.40, Volume: 4.27m
BE12:09pm

No biggie, says Liberum.

12:09 pm
BE12:09pm

esterday, the US Supreme Court voted 5-4 to overturn a 1992 physical presence requirement, which now frees states to collect an extra $8-23bn a year in sales tax, according to various estimates. Online companies can go to Congress to argue that only a small portion of their sales are affected in order to avoid additional tax charges. The current Nexus system means that local rates are applied at check-out where a company has a presence, be it a store, distribution centre or office. The proposed change to the regime means that in future states will be able to charge their own sales tax. Not only could this cause a change in current sales tax rates it adds additional unforeseen risks. While companies don’t disclose sales by region, we do expect potential different impacts across our coverage universe: in summary, no impact for Ted Baker, Joules, and Naked Wines, an immaterial impact for Boohoo and a modest but workable impact for ASOS.

BE12:09pm

Liberum view on coverage stocks: (i) ASOS (BUY, TP 8,000p) – in FY17 ASOS made £262m of US sales, representing 13% of group revenue. We understand the group has a physical presence in New York, Atlanta and South Dakota and already collects sales taxes in these locations. It does not have a physical presence California, where we believe a material percentage of US sales are made. Using New York as a proxy, where ASOS has a physical presence and a threshold of $110 item applies, suggests that the current 9% New York sales tax averages down to 5%. We understand that the average blended US sales tax for ASOS is c.2%. Under the potential new tax regime, we estimate that the new blended rate could increase to c.5%, meaning a potential incremental headwind in the high single digit millions. This is before any pass through to customers or other mitigating action that could be taken. Overall, we see the impact as workable; (ii) Boohoo (HOLD, TP 220p) – in FY18 Boohoo made £93m of US sales, which accounted for 16% of group revenue. We understand that the majority of sales are made in New York and California, where the group has a physical presence and already collects taxes. On this basis, we expect the potential tax regime change would pose an immaterial headwind; (iii) Majestic Wine* (BUY, TP 535p) – in FY18 Naked Wines generated £62m of US sales, representing 13% of the group. Naked has already adopted a destination based tax approach meaning there would be no impact from a change to the US tax regime; (iv) Ted Baker* (BUY, TP 3,300p) – TED’s portfolio of 32 US stores, with a broad geographic spread, means it has a physical presence where it generates most of its US sales and therefore already collects taxes in these locations. We would expect an immaterial impact from a change to the US tax regime; and (v) Joules* (BUY, TP 420p) – the group has a physical presence in New York and already collects taxes there, where we believe the majority of sales are made. Again we would expect an immaterial impact from any changes to the US tax regime.

Pharma #US sales tax. About time. Stupid rule that killed state finances for no good reason.
BE12:10pm

And Barclays

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

ASOS already collects sales tax in New York, Massachusetts and Ohio. We would estimate these three states are greater than 40% of its US business (its largest three states are New York, California and Texas). And in New York no sales tax is collected on apparel items below $110 – a lot of ASOS orders would be below this with an average basket of c$95. We would estimate the blended sales tax is c2% on these states and nothing will change here.

Tom Dalgleish US Supreme Court.......candle in the wind
BE12:11pm

We add a bit more than the 5% blended rate (we go with 6% given California has a high sales tax and is a big state for AOS) to the other 60% of their US business.

· So net net the sales tax ASOS has to pay should go from c0.8% (2% on 40% of the business) to c4.4% (2% on 40% and 6% on 60%).

· If this were to all kick in at the start of FY19 (it could well take longer) and ASOS were to take the full hit, we think it would knock c£14m of EBIT, worth about 50bps on group EBIT margin. It might in reality be less if some can be passed onto customers (that depends on how competition reacts).

BE12:11pm

Given the importance of holding the 4% EBIT margin in terms of the way the market views the ASOS story, we think in reality this will manifest as a headwind to growth rather than a margin downgrade. This is difficult to quantify but will likely present a headwind to FY19 / 20 (depending on timings).
